node.title: Columbus Reaches $5.75 Million Settlement Agreement With Protesters
node.alt: The police used pepper spray on demonstrators near the Ohio Statehouse in Columbus on May 30, 2020, days after the death of George Floyd .Â
node.description: Under the deal, which is subject to City Council approval, the money would go to 32 plaintiffs who said they were injured by the police during 2020 social justice protests.
node.content: ["The city of Columbus, Ohio, announced on Thursday that it had reached an agreement to pay $5.75 million to 32 plaintiffs who said that they were injured and that their constitutional rights were violated by members of the city\u2019s police division during social justice protests in the summer of 2020.", "After the killing of George Floyd last year, the plaintiffs were among many in Columbus who participated in protests that swept the country. The plaintiffs alleged in a lawsuit filed last year in U.S. District Court in the Southern District of Ohio that officers with the Columbus Police Division had used excessive force against them and had violated their constitutional rights.", "In announcing the settlement agreement, which is subject to City Council approval, the Columbus City Attorney\u2019s Office said that during the protests the police had \u201cmade arrests and used force including, but not limited to, pepper spray, tear gas, wooden baton rounds, and sponge rounds.\u201d", "Some plaintiffs were \u201csignificantly injured\u201d during the protests, Zach Klein, the city attorney, said in the statement, adding that it was \u201cincumbent upon the city to accept responsibility and pay restitution.\u201d", "\u201cWhile this has certainly been a difficult and painful moment for our community, it has yielded important, and in some instances long overdue, reforms to policing practices, policies, and oversight,\u201d said Mr. Klein, who noted that the money for the settlement would come from the city\u2019s general fund.", "\u201cThis settlement is a good step forward for both the Division of Police and for the entire community because it sets defined parameters and clear expectations for all when exercising and protecting First Amendment rights in Columbus,\u201d he said.", "Mr. Klein said that many Columbus police officers performed their jobs \u201cprofessionally\u201d during the protests, \u201cbut this litigation highlighted serious issues that must be addressed.\u201d", "Earlier this year, three Columbus police officers were charged with misconduct in connection with the protests, and Mr. Klein said that others could face charges.", "Also this year, after an evidentiary hearing, Chief Judge Algenon L. Marbley of U.S. District Court granted a preliminary injunction that barred the Columbus police from \u201cusing nonlethal force, including tear gas, pepper spray, rubber bullets, wooden pellets, and more on nonviolent protesters,\u201d according to a statement from the city.", "As part of the settlement, the city would agree to make the injunction permanent.", "In a statement, Tamara K. Alsaada, one of the plaintiffs in the case, said that \u201cone of the problems we face with policing in America is the deep-seated hostility of law enforcement to anyone who questions or exposes the racism and violent attitudes of many within police departments.\u201d", "At least three of the plaintiffs sustained broken bones, according to court documents. Mr. Klein said that because each plaintiff had different injuries the settlement amount would not be split evenly, and that a mediator would determine damages and settlement amounts for each plaintiff.", "In a statement, Robert Clark, director of the Columbus Department of Public Safety, said that the settlement was a \u201cstep toward\u201d repairing relationships that \u201chave been damaged.\u201d", "\u201cWe recognize what a painful chapter this has been for everyone involved, including the women and men of the Columbus Division of Police and the community we serve,\u201d Mr. Clark said. \u201cBefore there can be healing, there must be accountability.\u201d", "Chanda Brown, a lawyer for demonstrators, said in a statement that change was needed to \u201caddress the reality that many officers target anyone who questions their authority.\u201d"]
